summary: Email correspondence between an FBI agent and attorney Robert C. Josefsberg regarding counseling services for victims of Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI agent informs Josefsberg about updated counseling session caps for Florida victims, requiring prior approval from the case agent.

persons.name: Robert C. Josefsberg
persons.context: Attorney communicating with an FBI agent about counseling services for his clients who are victims of Jeffrey Epstein. He mentions he will inform his clients about the counseling offer.

persons.name: Brittany Henderson
persons.context: Sent an email to Robert Josefsberg regarding victims of Jeffrey Epstein and wanting to set up a telephone call to discuss therapeutic services.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the perpetrator whose victims are the subject of the email discussion regarding counseling services.

connections.description: Josefsberg represents clients who are victims of Jeffrey Epstein, indicating an attorney-client relationship with the victims regarding the Epstein case.
Henderson contacted Josefsberg to set up a call regarding therapeutic services for Epstein victims, indicating a professional correspondence.

events.title: Email about victim counseling services
events.description: FBI agent emails attorney Robert Josefsberg to inform him that the FBI Victim Assistance program will pay for counseling sessions for Epstein victims, with updated caps for Florida residents.

events.title: Previous meeting in Miami
events.description: Reference to a past meeting in Miami where it was discussed that the FBI Victim Assistance would pay for up to six counseling sessions for victims.

keyFacts: The FBI Victim Assistance program is offering to pay for counseling sessions for victims of Jeffrey Epstein.
For victims residing in Florida, there is a cap of 12 counseling sessions, but all sessions must be approved by the case agent prior to commencement.
Attorney Robert C. Josefsberg represents multiple clients who are victims of Jeffrey Epstein and is coordinating with the FBI regarding these counseling services.
A previous meeting in Miami was held to discuss the initial offer of up to six counseling sessions for victims.
